cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as a group of concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. The Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Astral Dominant
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Model
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Astral Plane
planes.philosophicalEssence: A realm of thought and dream, where visitors travel as disembodied souls to reach the Outer Planes.

physicalProperties.shape: A great silvery sea, the same above and below, with swirling wisps of white and gray streaking among motes of light
physicalProperties.atmosphereNotes: Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst.

temperature.description: No specific temperature mentioned; the plane is a silvery void

timeFlow.description: Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst. For this reason, creatures that live on the Astral Plane (such as githyanki) establish outposts on other planes, often the Material Plane, so their children can grow to maturity.

hazards.name: Psychic Wind
hazards.description: A psychic wind is a storm of thought that batters travelers' minds rather than their bodies. The storm is made of lost memories, forgotten ideas, and subconscious fears that went astray in the Astral Plane and conglomerated into this powerful force. A psychic wind is first sensed as a rapid darkening of the silver-gray sky. After 1d4 minutes, the area becomes as dark as a moonless night. As the sky darkens, the traveler feels buffeting and shaking. As quickly as it comes, the psychic wind passes, and the sky returns to normal in 1 minute.

savingThrowToTraverse.triggerDescription: Each traveler caught in a psychic wind makes a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw.

onFailure.description: On a failed save, the traveler suffers a random effect from the Psychic Wind Psychic Effects table.

onSuccess.description: The traveler avoids the psychic effect.

entries.description: At the end of the travel time, the characters arrive at a location other than the intended destination

entries.effect: Sent through a random color pool
entries.description: Roll on the Astral Color Pools table to determine which plane the travelers are sent to

entries.durationDescription: Stunned for 1 minute; repeat the saving throw at the end of each of your turns, ending the effect on yourself on a success.
Unconscious for 5 (1d10) hours; the effect ends if you take damage or if another creature takes an action to shake you awake.

environmentalEffects.name: Timeless Body
environmentalEffects.description: Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: No aging, no hunger, no thirst. Creatures that live on the Astral Plane establish outposts on other planes so their children can grow to maturity.

environmentalEffects.name: Thought-Based Movement
environmentalEffects.description: A traveler in the Astral Plane can move by simply thinking about moving. In combat, a creature has a Fly Speed (in feet) equal to 5 times its Intelligence score and can hover.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Fly Speed = 5 × Intelligence score (in feet), with hover. Distance has little meaning outside combat.

gravityModel.description: No gravity; creatures move by thinking about the desired direction of travel.

environmentalEffects.name: Thought-Based Navigation
environmentalEffects.description: All that is required to find one's destination is to think about it. As long as the destination is somewhere in the Astral Plane or in Wildspace, thinking about a place makes the creature aware of the most direct route to that location. The creature doesn't know how long the journey will take or how perilous it will be, just which direction to go in.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Thinking about a destination reveals the most direct route. Travel to a specific location takes 4d6 days. Travel to a general location such as a color pool leading to a specified plane takes 1d4 × 10 hours.

portals.name: Color Pool to the Ethereal Plane
Color Pool to the Material Plane
Color Pool to the Nine Hells

civilizations.name: Githyanki
civilizations.description: Creatures that live on the Astral Plane, establishing outposts on other planes so their children can grow to maturity.
civilizations.location: Various outposts, including Tu'narath built on a dead god's corpse

specialRules.name: Color Pool Identification
specialRules.description: Gateways leading from the Astral Plane to other planes appear as two-dimensional pools of rippling colors, 1d6 × 10 feet in diameter. Color, as with everything in the Astral Plane, is a matter of metaphor; since these portals are perceived by the Astral self and not by physical eyes, their colors are understood rather than seen. Traveling to another plane requires locating a color pool that leads to the desired plane. These gateways can be identified by color, as shown on the Astral Color Pools table.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Color pools are two-dimensional, rippling, colored gateways. Size: 1d6 × 10 feet in diameter (10 to 60 feet). Each color corresponds to a specific destination plane and can be identified on sight. Colors are perceived metaphorically by the Astral self rather than by physical eyes. Roll d20 on the Astral Color Pools table to determine a random color pool's destination.

specialRules.name: Color Pool Navigation via Thought
specialRules.description: As long as the destination is somewhere in the Astral Plane, such as 'the nearest color pool leading to the Abyss,' thinking about a place makes the creature aware of the most direct route to that location. The creature doesn't know how long the journey will take or how perilous it will be, just which direction to go in.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Thinking about a color pool leading to a specified plane reveals the most direct route. Travel time to a general destination such as a color pool takes 1d4 × 10 hours. Travel to a specific location takes 4d6 days.

specialRules.name: Psychic Wind Color Pool Redirect
specialRules.description: A psychic wind location effect (d20 roll 17-20) can send travelers through a random color pool. Roll on the Astral Color Pools table to determine the destination.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: On a Psychic Wind Location Effects roll of 17-20, travelers are sent through a random color pool. Roll d20 on the Astral Color Pools table to determine the destination plane.

crossReferences.description: Contains extensive information about Wildspace and Astral travel.

planarTravelMethods.name: Astral Color Pools
planarTravelMethods.description: Gateways leading from the Astral Plane to other planes appear as two-dimensional pools of rippling colors, 1d6 × 10 feet in diameter. Color is a matter of metaphor, perceived by the Astral self and not by physical eyes—their colors are understood rather than seen. Traveling to another plane requires locating a color pool that leads to the desired plane. These gateways can be identified by color as shown on the Astral Color Pools table (d20).
requirements: Must be on the Astral Plane
Must locate a color pool of the appropriate color for the desired destination
risks: Psychic wind may divert travelers or send them through a random color pool
Travel time is uncertain (1d4 × 10 hours to reach a color pool leading to a specified plane)

planarTravelMethods.name: Astral Projection
planarTravelMethods.description: Astral Projection lets adventurers project themselves into the Astral Plane and from there travel to the Outer Planes.

planarAdventureSituations.situation: When magic fails to revive a dead person, the only solution is to venture to the Outer Planes to find the person's spirit and either release it from some prison or convince the person to return to life.

People who venture into the woods keep accidentally wandering into the Feywild or the Shadowfell. They might never return, return with no sense of how much time has passed, or return dramatically changed.
A long-dead oracle is the only one who knows how a terrible prophecy might be averted, but the cataclysmic fulfillment of the prophecy has already begun.
A god has stopped answering prayers and won't respond to any Commune spell.
A devil has tricked an angel into meddling in the Blood War, and the angel seeks mortal aid.
An ancestor of one of the characters must be convinced to bless the character before the full power of the character's bloodline can be unleashed.
A foolhardy knight carried a holy weapon on a doomed mission into the Nine Hells, and the powers of Mount Celestia want the weapon and the knight's remains retrieved.
A titan is imprisoned on an Outer Plane. The characters might be trying to stop those who seek to release it, or they might want to release it to help defend the world from a greater threat.

To prove themselves worthy of an even greater quest, the characters are sent to slay a horrible monster, win the favor of a powerful planar being, negotiate peace between two warring planar factions, or retrieve a long-lost item on another plane.
An item of legend is being sold at auction in Sigil, the City of Brass, or some other planar metropolis.

globalPlanarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit the Lower Planes and Fiends who visit the Upper Planes experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to its nature, a Celestial or Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to the creature's nature.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: Each failed save adds an additional 1d4 subtracted from D20 Tests.

onSuccess.description: The creature resists the dissonance for this rest period.

savingThrow.repeatSaveTiming: After each Long Rest on the opposed plane
recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
